Name: Air temperature of lakes on-buoy
description: Air temperature observations are made on the meteorology station on the buoy in lakes and rivers.

Name: Suface temperature in lakes
description: Sensor based measurements of water temperature in lake and river sites. Temperature is measured at the surface with temperature sensors.

Shortwave radiation is a radiant energy produced by the sun with wavelengths ranging from infrared through visible to ultraviolet (300-4000 nm). Incoming shortwave radiation is measured on towers near the lake site.

Name: Photosynthetically active radiation below water surface
description: Photosynthetically Active Radiation (PAR) observations represent the radiation flux at wavelengths between 400-700 nm, which constitute the wavelengths that drive photosynthesis. Observations are made at the at the lake surface.

Name: Dissolved Inorganic Nitrogen
description: Nitrogen is available for phytoplankton uptake in the form of dissolved inorganic nitrogen. It is comprised of nitrate plus nitrite and ammonium. These forms of nitrogen are readily available for uptake by phytoplankton and often control the formation of algal blooms.

Name: Nitrate in surface water
description: In situ sensor-based nitrate concentration in surface water in lakes.

Chlorophyll-a is measured in lakes to determine how much algae is in the lake. Algae is important in lakes because it adds oxygen to the water as a by-product of photosynthesis but if there is too much algae in a lake it can produce a foul odor and be unpleasant for swimming. Chlorophyll-a concentration can tell you a lot about the lake's water quality and trophic state.

Name: Secchi depth
description: It is the depth that the Secchi disk can no longer be seen through the water. A Secchi disk is divided into quadrants painted alternately black and white and is lowered into the water slowly until it can no longer be seen.

Name: Dissolved Oxygen
description: Dissolved Oxygen (DO) is the amount of oxygen dissolved in lake water. Oxygen is necessary for all living organisms to survive except for some bacteria. Living organisms breathe in oxygen that is dissolved in the water. The amount of oxygen lake water can hold is directly related to temperature. The colder the water, the more dissolved oxygen it can hold.
